title-group.article-title: Holocaust Memories, Historians' Memoirs:First-Person Narrative and the Memory of the Holocaust

ref.mixed-citation:
On the general phenomenon of historians' autobiographies, see Jeremy D. Popkin ,“Historians on the Autobiographical Frontier,”
American Historical Review
104(1999),725–48; and Michael Dintenfass ,“Crafting Historians' Lives: Autobiographical Constructions and Disciplinary Discourses after the Linguistic Turn,”
Journal of Modern History
71(1999):150–65. The books discussed in this essay are Reuben Ainsztein , In Lands Not My Own: A Wartime Journey (,2002); Peter Alter , ed., Out of the Third Reich: Refugee Historians in Post-War Britain (,1998), with autobiographical essays by 13 German- and Austrian-born historical scholars: Julius Carlebach , Francis Carsten , Edgar Feuchtwanger , J. A. S. Grenville , E. P. Hennock , Helmut Koenigsberger , Wolf Mendl , Werner Mosse , Helmut Pappe , Arnold Paucker , Sidney Pollard , Peter Pulzer , Nicholai Rubinstein and Walter Ullmann ; Susan Groag Bell , Between Worlds: In Czechoslovakia, England, and America (,1991); Reinhard Bendix , From Berlin to Berkeley: German-Jewish Identities (,1986); Helmut Eschwege , Fremd unter Meinesgleichen: Erinnerungen eines Dresdener Juden (,1991); Saul Friedländer , When Memory Comes , trans. Helen R. Lane (,1980); Evyatar Friesel , The Days and the Seasons (,1996); Peter Gay , My German Question: Growing Up in Nazi Berlin (,1998); Felix Gilbert , A European Past: Memoirs, 1905–1945 (,1988); Walter Grab , Meine vier Leben (,1999); Alfred Grosser , Une vie de français (,1997); Theodore S. Hamerow , Remembering a Vanished World: A Jewish Childhood in Interwar Poland (,2001); Raul Hilberg , The Politics of Memory: The Journey of a Holocaust Historian (,1996); Eric Hobsbawm , Interesting Times: A Twentieth-Century Life (,2002); Wilma and Georg Iggers , Zwei Seiten der Geschichte: Lebensbericht aus unruhigen Zeiten (,2002); Jacob Katz , With My Own Eyes: The Autobiography of an Historian , trans. Ann Brenner and Zipora Brody (,1995); Peter Kenez , Varieties of Fear: Growing Up Jewish under Nazism and Communism (,1995); Annie Kriegel , Ce que jʾai cru comprendre (,1991); Jürgen Kuczynski , Memoiren: Die Erziehung des J. K. zum Kommunisten und Wissenschaftler (1971;,1981) and “Ein Linientreue Dissident”: Memoiren 1945–1989 (,1992); Walter Laqueur , Thursdayʾs Child Has Far to Go (,1995); Gerda Lerner , Fireweed: A Political Autobiography (,2002); Gerhard Masur , Das ungewisse Herz: Berichte aus Berlin—über die Suche nach dem Freien (,1978); George Mosse , Confronting History (,2000); Léon Poliakov , Mémoires , new ed. (,1999); Dan Vittorio Segre , Memoirs of a Fortunate Jew (,1987); Hans Schmitt , Lucky Victim: An Ordinary Life in Extraordinary Times (,1989); Herbert A. Strauss , In the Eye of the Storm: Growing Up Jewish in Germany, 1918–1943 (,1999); Nechama Tec , Dry Tears: The Story of a Lost Childhood (,1982); and Pierre Vidal-Naquet , Mémoires: La brisure et lʾattente (,1995), and Le Trouble et la lumière (,1998). The earliest of these books, the first volume of Jürgen Kuczynski's memoirs, was published in 1971; the most recent works in the list, those of Reuben Ainsztein, Eric Hobsbawm, Georg Iggers and Gerda Lerner, came out in 2002. The oldest author, Gerhard Masur, was born in 1901; the youngest, Peter Kenez, in 1936. I have had some contact, personally or in writing, with a number of these authors, and would like to thank Saul Friedländer, Evyatar Friesel, Peter Gay, Alfred Grosser, Peter Kenez, Walter Laqueur, Gerda Lerner, Hans Schmitt, and the late George Mosse in particular for their comments on various aspects of my work on historians and autobiography, and, in some cases, for their responses to earlier versions of this paper. Reinhard Bendix, one of my teachers at Berkeley in the 1970s, died before my work had led me to an interest in his memoirs.

For Ricoeur's discussion of the distinctions between historical and fictional narratives, see Paul Ricoeur , Temps et récit , vol.3(,1985), ch. 1,“Entre le temps vécu et le temps universel: Le temps historique,” 153–81.
G. Kitson Clark , The Critical Historian (,1967),67.

Among the books that established autobiography as a major topic among literary scholars after 1970, see James Olney , Metaphors of Self: The Meaning of Autobiography (,1972), Philippe Lejeune , On Autobiography , trans. Katherine Leary (,1989), and Paul John Eakin , Fictions in Autobiography: Studies in the Art of Self-Invention (,1985). The literature on autobiographical theory has expanded exponentially in the past few decades, and even the scholars who launched the current vogue of interest in the topic have often changed their attitudes toward the subject. For a useful overview of these developments, see Laura Marcus , Auto/biographical Discourses: Theory, Criticism, Practice (,1994).

Hayden White , Metahistory (,1973). For one literary theorist's use of White to question the distinction between history and fictional narrative, see Paul John Eakin , Touching the World: Reference in Autobiography (,1992),177.

Christopher Browning ,“German Memory, Judicial Interrogation, and Historical Reconstruction: Writing Perpetrator History from Postwar Testimony,”and Hayden White ,“Historical Emplotment and the Problem of Truth,”in Saul Friedländer , ed., Probing the Limits of Representation: Nazism and the “Final Solution” (,1992),22–36and37–53.

“Random House to Aid Holocaust Memoir Project,”
New York Times ,4 Oct. 2000.
David Patterson , Sun Turned to Darkness (,1998),12.

Hilberg , The Politics of Memory ,132. The phrase “I did not interview the dead” was the title of one of the first collections of survivors' testimony, put together by David Boder immediately after the war. See Donald L. Niewyk , ed., Fresh Wounds: Early Narratives of Holocaust Survival (,1998),5, which reprints some of Boder's interviews.
Frank Kermode , Not Entitled: A Memoir (,1995),155–56.

The Holocaust historians: Ainsztein, Eschwege, Friedländer, Hilberg, Strauss, Poliakov, Tec; those with at least one major book on related issues, either some aspect of Holocaust, German or German Jewish history in the pre-Hitler era or the development of anti-Semitism: Carsten, Gay, Gilbert, Katz, Laqueur, Mosse, Schmitt, Vidal-Naquet; those who never wrote on the subject outside of their memoirs: Bell, Bendix, Friesel, Grab, Grosser, Hamerow, Hobsbawm, Iggers, Kenez, Kriegel, Kuczynski, Lerner, Masur, Segre, and all but one of the 13 contributors to the Alter volume.

Léon Poliakov'sMémoiresis a composite text: the section on the war years was apparently composed in 1946 but never published, and supplemented much later with chapters covering his life before and after the Holocaust period.

Mitchell Hart ,“The Historian's Past in Three Recent Jewish Autobiographies,”
Jewish Social Studies , n.s.,3, no.3(1999):135.

The only memoirs by academics who were actually in the camps that I have encountered so far are Ruth Klüger , weiter leben (,1994), by a literature scholar, and David Weiss Halivni , The Book and the Sword (,1996), by a scholar of rabbinics. Halivni claims that “there are not many academicians among the survivors.…” (160) The only historian-memoirists whose memoirs include stories of camp confinement are Reuben Ainsztein, who was interned in Spain for several years after escaping from France, and those like Jürgen Kuczynski, who were held as enemy aliens in England in 1940.

Grab , Meine vier Leben ,57. After terrorizing their captives, the Nazis did give them rags to work with, and Grab managed to talk his way out of the ordeal, but the experience remained traumatic. Lerner , Fireweed ,94–113.
Halivni , The Book and the Sword ,158.

It might be argued that the brush with the Holocaust is incidental in a few of these volumes, namely those whose titles do not explicitly allude to the experience and in the texts of which one finds relatively little reflection of the event in comparison to other aspects of the authors' lives. Eric Hobsbawm's, Annie Kriegel's, Jürgen Kuczynski's, and Jacob Katz's memoirs would be at one end of the spectrum in this regard; Nechama Tec, who writes exclusively about her six years in German-occupied Poland, would be at the other extreme.
Elie Wiesel , Memoirs: All Rivers Run to the Sea (,1995).

Ka-Tzetnik 135663, Kaddish (,1998),70. On Ka-Tzetnik's autobiographical practice, see Jeremy D. Popkin ,“Ka-Tzetnik 135633: The Survivor as Pseudonym,”
New Literary History
33, no.2(2002),343–55.

An important exception to this tendency is Ruth Klüger's memoir,weiter leben, in which the difference in viewpoint between the autobiographical author and the person she was during the Holocaust is a major theme.
Friedländer , When Memory Comes ,6; Lerner , Fireweed ,32.
Kriegel , Ce que jʾai cru comprendre ,49.
Iggers , Zwei Seiten der Geschichte ,60–63; Strauss , In the Eye of the Storm ,8.
Segre , Memoirs of a Fortunate Jew ,237–40.
Kriegel , Ce que jʾai cru comprendre ,195.

Moshe Lewin, a historian of the Soviet period who spent the Holocaust years in Russia before emigrating to Israel, makes similar comments about Israel in the 1950s in his autobiographical interview, in Henry Abelove et al., eds., Visions of History (,1984),286.
Friesel , The Days and the Seasons ,180; Gay , My German Question ,203–4.
Bendix,“American Sociologist,”in Bennett M. Berger , ed., Authors of Their Own Lives: Intellectual Autobiographies of American Sociologists (,1990),470–74.

John Burt Foster ,“Cultural Multiplicity in Two Modern Autobiographies: Friedländer'sWhen Memory Comesand Dinesen'sOut of Africa,”
Southern Humanities Review
29, no.3(1995):210.
Kriegel , Ce que jʾai cru comprendre ,761,783.
Friesel , The Days and the Seasons ,9; Hennock ,“Myself as Historian,”in Alter , ed., Out of the Third Reich ,87.
Werner Mosse ,“Self-Discovery: A European Historian,”in Alter , ed., Out of the Third Reich ,158.

Sebastien Haffner , Defying Hitler: A Memoir , trans. Oliver Pretzel (,2002). Haffner's memoir was written in 1939, soon after he left Germany for exile in England, but was only published after his death.

Jurgen Herbst , Requiem for a German Past: A Boyhood among the Nazis (,1999),228. Herbst's thoroughgoing rejection of his native culture is, of course, exceptional among his generation of non-Jewish German historians.

The Library of Congress, for example, has assigned Peter Gay'sMy German Questiona “DS” call number, placing it firmly in the category of Jewish history, even though its title makes no reference to Jews or Judaism.
Kriegel , Ce que jʾai cru comprendre ,753.

Hans Schmitt, criticizing historians' emphasis on elites who shaped public events, justifies autobiographies as“individual small steps toward a general upstairsdownstairs synthesis.”
Schmitt , Lucky Victim ,2.
